which (with Bagotville / Ville de la Baie and other surrounding towns) were combined officially to be one municipality of over a hundred thousand inhabitants, named "Saguenay" for the Saguenay River.
	
The region is strongly unilingual francophone; principal local industries have historically been forestry, paper (Abitibi, Price, Stone-Consolidated) and aluminium smelting (Alcan). CFB Bagotville is the local air force base; a community college (Collège de Jonquière) offers an intensive three-week immersion programme in French as a second language which has long attracted civil servants from
and draws students from as far as

.

Chicoutimi-Jonquière is geographically isolated as the two and a half hours of four-lane road leading into the municipality from

runs almost entirely on provincial parkland with just one opportunity to stop for fuel at the midpoint. There is cellular telephone service on the main road in, but along many other roads (such as Chicoutimi-Nord to Tadoussac) there is truly nothing.

As the largest city in-region, Chicoutimi serves as a jumping-off point to Lac St. Jean in the west and the Saguenay River to Tadoussac in the east:

value: is famous for its blueberries, to the point where locals in the region are referred to as "les bleuets" (literally, blueberries), with a Trappist monk group manufacturing tasty chocolate-covered blueberries and other confections in Mistassini at the far end of
. Other key landmarks around the lake are a zoo at St. Felicien, the tourist ghost town of Val-Jalbert (near Roberval) and a good collection of cycling and snowmobile trails.

, at the eastern end of the fjord of the Saguenay River, is notable primarily for whale-watching. Both sides of the Saguenay River fjord between La Baie and Tadoussac - St. Siméon are largely parkland with no services. Boat tours of the river and fjord depart from either endpoint.

from Tadoussac or Saint-Siméon, a highway follows the full length of the river on each side (Route 172 on the north shore, Route 170 on the south shore). There are no villages and no services on most of this route.

Taxis in Chicoutimi include A52 Taxi (+1 418-543-3868), Taxi Saint-Ambroise (+1 418-718-1414) and Taxis Unis (+1 418-543-3868)
Taxi service in Jonquière is offered by Taxi Diamond (+1 418-548-2121)
address=1831, 6e Avenue, ville de La Baie

content=Theatrical performance recounting the history of the region (as "the Saguenay Kingdom") from native settlement to colonial and pioneer times onward. Presented annually (originally in July) in French for 26 years, an abridged English-language version is now offered in the fall.
content=Regional museum. The Arthur Villeneuve house, painted inside and out with local scenes in a multi-year effort begun in 1957, was relocated here from 669 rue Taché ouest in Chicoutimi in 1994.
address=route du Pont, Arvida et Shipshaw

content=First all-aluminium arch bridge in North America, built 1950 by Alcan and Dominion Bridge Company to span the Saguenay River at Arvida and listed on the provincial historic register in 2004. Arvida, named for industrialist Arthur Vining Davis, was a planned community built around an aluminium factory which took advantage of plentiful hydroelectric power. Shipshaw was the second of two generating stations in-region. Both are now part of Jonquière (Saguenay).
content=Village near Shipshaw, abandoned after thirty-eight houses were destroyed in a landslide on May 4, 1971. A stone memorial marker, a crater and some damaged road are all that remain.
hours=June-mid Oct, runs daily from St. Jean (June 24) to Labour Day
content="Marjolaine II" cruises, charter and shuttle on Saguenay river, depart from La Baie (east of Chicoutimi).  ·

The main street of downtown Chicoutimi is la rue Racine; construction of shopping malls has greatly diminished the number of downtown businesses. Local confections such as maple syrup or chocolate blueberries are usually less expensive in the main street shops frequented by locals in the city than at tourist establishments... even for blueberries in Lac St. Jean itself.
The region is known for two dishes. Tourtière, a traditional French-Canadian meat pie, is named for

(the passenger pigeon), a bird of prey which was once common in Lac St. Jean but now extinct worldwide. More famous are the region's blueberries. Various farms around Lac St. Jean invite you to pick your own blueberries in season (usually August, weather permitting).

value: name= Papy Resto Pub steakhouse Chicoutimi

The main street of Jonquière (la rue Ste. Dominique, the "Saint Do") has a fairly extensive and notorious bar strip with several bars in close proximity. Some other options include:

value: content=Sports bar and restaurant. Steak, seafood, sandwiches.
address=4014, rue de la Fabrique, Jonquière
content=Cinema, music and live performance venue.

content=Microbrewery with eight local beers; a "sampling tower" offers a four-ounce taste of multiple beers on one tray. Brewery tours available for groups. Bistro with patio, live music on summer weekends.
content=Microbrewery with locations in Chicoutimi, Jonquière and Québec City.
content=On Rivière aux Sables south of Jonquière. Cycle path, heated outdoor pool, tennis court, restaurant, bistro, 67-room inn with seven meeting rooms.
content=Downtown main street hotel overlooking Saguenay fjord, 85 rooms, three restaurants, boutique in lobby with souvenirs and regional art.
